channel.title: Small Problem
channel.description:
I had used Ron's dual boot tutorial. Yes, it worked but after I decided to use Linux on a full HDD so I deleted the partition. I applied the changes and everything seemed fine until I shut down. The next day when I turned on the computer I had a nasty surprise when the computer was loading. It was GRUB: error 22. Yes I did google for answers but all the answers pointed out that I need my Windows Vista CD to fix that. But unfortunately, my laptop came without the CD. The thing is I need some of those files on my computer otherwise I would have just re-wrote linux and wiped the vista.
My English essay is due in 1 day but I got an extension of 5 days, and some important files that I have are on the partition. Can anyone help me?

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @nicatron nicatron
item.description:
@nicatron wrote:

get the knoppix live CD
www.knoppix.com click the american flag

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“dev eXer, post:10, topic:134085”]There was some error in the partition creation and now it seems I have no idea what the hell happened. The majority of my size was put into ext3 partition. And the nfts seems to have 7 GB left.

/dev/sda1 is ntfs
/dev/sda2 is ext3

I am so freaked out right now I don’t know what happened.[/quote]

Sounds like you just formatted over your windows partition to me.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @voiD_dev voiD dev
item.description:
@voiD_dev wrote:

Yes I did google for answers but all the answers pointed out that I need my Windows Vista CD to fix that. But unfortunately, my laptop came without the CD.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

If it’s error 22. Put in your windows cd, and go to System Recovery or whatever, and type; fixmbr I think.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @dev_eXer dev eXer
item.description:
@dev_eXer wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:9, topic:134085”][quote author=dev eXer link=topic=185435.msg1681617#msg1681617 date=1187376504]
Moparisthebest, I deleted that partition though
[/quote]

The LiveCD has a partitioning tool.[/quote]
Thanks, The Un-Named. I will try that.

[EDIT]: There was some error in the partition creation and now it seems I have no idea what the hell happened. The majority of my size was put into ext3 partition. And the nfts seems to have 7 GB left.

/dev/sda1 is ntfs
/dev/sda2 is ext3

I am so freaked out right now I don’t know what happened.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

dev eXer:

Moparisthebest, I deleted that partition though

The LiveCD has a partitioning tool.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

So just install linux on something else (another partition) dev eXer.

I really don’t know Painless, I have never had the need to resize a partition.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @dev_eXer dev eXer
item.description:
@dev_eXer wrote:

Moparisthebest, I deleted that partition though

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @Painless Painless
item.description:
@Painless wrote:

On the topic of this… How can you resize/delete a partition without grub going stupid? Trying to make my Linux Partition bigger, but whenever I try it. It comes up with Error 22.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Install linux on the partition that you wiped, it should still be there, if not resize the windows partition with the linux installer like you did the first time.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @dev_eXer dev eXer
item.description:
@dev_eXer wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:134085”]You should never have wiped the partition, GRUB resided on that partition and you deleted it

One thing you can do is reinstall linux so you can get GRUB back working and then you can boot into whatever you want to, including windows.[/quote]
But how would I do that without wiping my files because only the Windows partition is left.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You should never have wiped the partition, GRUB resided on that partition and you deleted it

One thing you can do is reinstall linux so you can get GRUB back working and then you can boot into whatever you want to, including windows.

Read full topic

item.title: Small Problem
item.dc:creator: @Painless Painless
item.description:
@Painless wrote:

I had this problem and I ended up just wiping the hdd. However I found out that I could get files that were on my Ubuntu partition by running the Live Disc.

Read full topic
